PROJECT PREPARATORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Justification 
1.  A multitranche financing facility (MFF) is proposed as the financing modality for the 
investment program because it allows the government to focus on institutional strengthening 
and project implementation, and to provide an optimal amount of timely financing by arranging 
contract packages in specialized components and/or a larger size. To prepare and implement 
the large investment program, technical assistance is required to assist the government in 
carrying out due diligence on project preparation, and in developing capacity necessary for 
project implementation.  
 
B.  Major Outputs and Activities 
2.  The proposed technical assistance (TA) will assist the government in (i) preparing due 
diligence required for civil works, and (ii) developing a mechanism for performance monitoring 
and information management. 
 
3.  Output 1: Due diligence required for civil works. The TA will support due diligence 
required for civil works by (i) reviewing the engineering design and technical standards, (ii) 
preparing  the  procurement  documents,  (iii)  developing  road  asset  management  plans,  (iv) 
verifying economic and financial analysis, (v) assessing the impact on poverty reduction and 
social aspects, (vi) undertaking environmental and social safeguard due diligence, and (vii) 
providing related trainings to RDA staff, consultants, and contractors. 
 
4.  Output 2: Mechanism of performance tracking and information management. The 
TA will develop a mechanism of performance tracking and information management for the 
investment program. The key activities will involve (i) assessing RDA’s capacity on performance 
tracking and information management, (ii) identifying the capacity gap, (iii) establishing an 
information  center,  and  (iv)  developing  protocols  for  performance  tracking  and  information 
management.

C.  Cost Estimate and Proposed Financing Arrangement  
6.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,000,000 equivalent, which will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB's Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-Others). The government will provide 
support in the form of counterpart staff, office accommodation, office supplies, and provision of 
all relevant and available documents, data, statistics, information, and maps. The detailed cost 
estimate is presented in Table A4.2.

D.  Consulting Services 
7.  In total the TA will require 54 person-months of consulting services (18 international and 
36 national). ADB will engage consultants in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants (2013, as amended from time to time). Disbursement under the TA will be carried

3 
 
out  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Disbursement  Handbook  (2010,  as 
amended  from  time  to  time).  Procurement  of  equipment  will  follow  ADB’s  Procurement 
Guidelines (2013, as amended from time to time). The equipment will be handed over to the 
government upon TA completion. A summary of consulting services requirement is presented in 
Table A4.3. 
 
8.  Output  1:  Due  diligence  required  for  civil  works.  Four  individual  international 
consultants  and  one  national  consultant  will  be  needed  with  expertise  in  (i)  road  asset 
management, (ii) output- and performance-based road contracts (OPRC), (iii) social safeguard, 
and (iv) environment safeguard.  
 
9.  Output 2: Mechanism of performance tracking and information management. A 
consulting firm will be engaged following the consultants’ qualifications selection (CQS) method. 
One international consultant and two national consultants will be needed with expertise in 
Geospatial Information System (GIS) and Information Technology (IT).

10.  The outline terms of reference for the project preparatory TA consultants are described 
in paras. 11 to 17.  
 
11.  Road Asset Management Advisor (9 international person-months). The road asset 
management advisor preferably has a bachelor degree of civil engineering, at least 15 years of 
relevant experience in road asset management with a focus on its application in OPRC type 
projects. The main tasks under the TA include preparing benchmark asset management plan for 
contract packages, providing inputs for cost estimation, reviewing bidding documents, preparing 
protocols for data collection, developing a mechanism for performance tracking, and providing 
trainings to address the capacity weakness of RDA. 
 
12.  OPRC Specialist (4 international person-months). The OPRC specialist preferably has 
a  bachelor  degree  of  civil  engineering,  at  least  15  years  of  relevant  experience  in  the 
procurement and implementation of civil works in road projects with a focus on OPRC type 
projects. The main tasks under the TA include assisting RDA in preparing bidding documents 
for the contract packages, estimating costs for OPRC packages, assisting RDA in procuring the 
civil works, and providing trainings to address the capacity weakness of RDA and contractors. 
 
13.  Social  Safeguard  Specialist (1  international person-months). The  social  safeguard 
specialist preferably has a bachelor degree of social development or related areas, at least 10 
years  of  relevant  experience  in  social  safeguards,  including  social  development,  poverty

4 
reduction, land acquisition and resettlement, and indigenous people. The main tasks under the 
TA include assisting RDA in preparing community participation framework from the perspective 
of social safeguard, and in carrying out social safeguard related due diligence. 
 
14.  Environment Safeguard Specialist (1 international person-months). The environment 
safeguard specialist preferably has a bachelor degree of environment or related areas, at least 
10 years of relevant experience in environment safeguards. The main tasks under the TA 
include assisting RDA in preparing community participation framework from the perspective of 
environment safeguard, and in carrying out environment safeguard related due diligence. 
 
15.  Transport Analyst (18 national person-months). The transport analyst preferably has a 
bachelor degree of civil engineering, at least 8 years of relevant experience in the transport 
sector. The main tasks under the TA include assisting RDA in data collection and analysis. 
 
16.  GIS Specialist (3 international person-months). The GIS specialist preferably has a 
bachelor degree of GIS-related subjects, at least 15 years of relevant experience in the GIS-
related projects and preferably in the transport sector. The main tasks under the TA include 
assisting RDA in designing, procuring, installing, and operating a GIS-based information center 
to  implement  the  mechanism  of  performance  tracking  and  information  management,  and 
providing trainings on GIS operation.  
 
17.  IT Specialists (national, 18 person-months). Two national IT specialists will be engaged 
to assist the GIS specialist. The IT specialists preferably has a bachelor degree of IT-related 
subjects, at least 8 years of relevant experience in the IT projects and preferably for transport 
sector. The main tasks under the TA include assisting the GIS specialist in preparing technical 
specifications of the information center, testing the hardware and software, and provide on-the-
job training on the operation of information center. 
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
18.  The MOPH  will be the executing agency to supervise and coordinate TA activities 
through  RDA. The government  will  provide  (i)  all  relevant  and  available  documents,  data, 
statistics, information, and maps; (ii) a TA coordinator from the RDA, to be assigned before the 
consultants are mobilized; (iii) counterpart staff from MOPH and RDA, to be assigned before the 
consultants are mobilized; (iv) office accommodation, office equipment, including desks and 
chairs, and local communication in Colombo, and utility costs, covering electricity and water; 
and  (v)  logistical  assistance  for  the  workshops  and  seminars,  including  the  venue,  and 
identifying  and  inviting  the  participants.  The  proposed  TA  processing  and  implementation 
schedule is listed in Table A4.4.
